column4: What is the command to login to a broken system after booting into a live cd on that machine?
What's broken about your system?
fsck found errors but said that there's a package called less missing so it doesn't proceed with repair (I think that's what stops it).
centaur, You can boot into safe mode from the GRUB at the beginning.
tried that and fsck starts scanning again and I can't even get an ip address from my network to install the missing applications it complains about.
less is a simple little console application that let's you view page by page information in a file, that's a weird error.
It's been over a year since I've had my system broken to where it wouldn't boot and I came across a howto on logging into the broken system from a live cd to run commands on that installation.
less comes with ubuntu by default.
What did you do to cause this error or did it just happen out of no where?
I figured it's supposed to already be on there as well.
Well I haven't had my machine on for 2 days but the last thing I was doing was using the live cd to transfer files off my hd to a sd card.
Why were you using the live cd and not just booting unto  your hard disk?

Cause I'm using gutsy and it doesn't automatically mount sd cards anymore so I manually mounted my sd card and transferred some things to it but then it wouldn't unmount so I couldn't switch to use my 2nd sd card so I booted into the live cd to finish the job.
centaur, Weird, heh.  Yeah, I'd search around about making recovery CD's, and the file to edit to skip the fsck scan.
centaur, I am pretty sure there's a console recovery mode where you got line by line of your boot up and it asks you yes/no whether or not you want to perform that command.
perhaps funning fsck from the live cd and having it finish the job that way will fix it?
Couldn't hurt.
Okay, I'll try that real quick and see where that gets me. I've been running a long time without a non-bootable machine even with alfa and beta installs.  :)
centaur, Good luck.
that fixed it. thanks for your help!
The only error found by fsck was that there were large files in the file system but no support for them was enabled.
centaur, You figured it out on your own, I was just a sounding board.  ;)
Well I needed an audience while I thought out loud.  :)
